quoteFirst: But two British torpedo-boats had now arrived, and at
quoteLast: , when off Bolt Tail, with Plymouth Sound only a few miles off, the _Stockforce’s_ captain had to send the rest of the ship’s company from the sinking ship, while he remained on board with only the first lieutenant.
title: Q-Ships and Their Story
author: Chatterton, E. Keble (Edward Keble), 1878-1944

quoteFirst: “Now, look here, ye omadhaun, this gentleman _must_ be called with a cup of tea at a
quoteLast: to-morrow morning in order to catch his train at six. If you let him lose that train I’ll kill ye as dead as meat.
title:
Recollections
The Reminiscences of the Busy Life of One Who Has Played the Varied Parts of Sailor, Author & Lecturer
author: Bullen, Frank Thomas, 1857-1915

quoteFirst: He consulted the railway time-tables for me, made many inquiries of the guards, whom he appeared to disbelieve, for he went back to the time-tables again; finally told me that there was no train till
quoteLast: by which I could reach home. He showed me an hotel adjacent to the station, and left me there, after again upbraiding me for my want of judgment; and at a quarter past five--what an age it seemed before that time came round!--I left Ashford once again for home."
title: Mattie:—A Stray (Vol 2 of 3)
author: Robinson, F. W. (Frederick William), 1830-1901

quoteFirst: He glanced up at the large dock.  It was
title: The Temptress
author: Le Queux, William, 1864-1927

quoteLast: as you trudge down Waterloo-place on your way to the Golden Cross, and you discover, for the first time, that you were called about an hour too early. You have not time to go back; there is no place open to go into, and you have, therefore, no resource but to go forward, which you do, feeling remarkably satisfied with yourself, and everything about you.
title: Sketches by Boz, Illustrative of Every-Day Life and Every-Day People
author: Dickens, Charles, 1812-1870

quoteFirst: To look at our ground of a year ago,[2542] from which we had started for Jūnpūr,[2543] I went to about a _kuroh_ lower than the mouth of the Jūnpūr-water (Gūmtī). A favourable wind getting up behind, our larger boat was tied to a smaller Bengalī one which, spreading its sail, made very quick going. Two _garīs_ of day remained (
quoteLast: ) when we had reached that ground (Sayyidpur?), we went on without waiting there, and by the Bed-time Prayer had got to camp, which was a _kuroh_ above Madan-Benāres,[2544] long before the boats following us. Mughūl Beg had been ordered to measure all marches from Chunār on the direct road, Luṯfī Beg to measure the river's bank whenever I went by boat.
title: The Bābur-nāma in English (Memoirs of Bābur)
author: Babur, Emperor of Hindustan, 1483-1530; Beveridge, Annette Susannah, 1842-1929 [Translator]

quoteLast: in the morning, his usual hour, to watch his men going to work.

quoteFirst: Slaughter went around detailing men to posts and duties.  I remained with my section of nine men.  [Sidenote: _
quoteLast: , April 19th, 1916._] It must have been about 5.15 p.m.  when they opened up again, as I remember Sergt. Slaughter inquiring for me about 4.55 p.m. 'what time it was, and if the rifles Were clean and ready?'  I might have mentioned that during the bombardment, Mr.
title: Canada in Flanders, Volume II
